Award.AwardTitle: Spatiotemporal Dynamics of Bedload Sediment Flux in Large Rivers

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION
GEOGRAPHY SPATIAL SCIENCES (GSS) PROGRAM

ABSTRACT

This research project will provide new knowledge regarding global-scale predictions and analysis of sediment fluxes in large rivers, with special attention given to sediment transported in riverbeds. The investigator will develop a globally distributed, bedload-flux computer model to analyze the spatial interactions between bedload and environmental dynamics as well as the ratio between bedload and sediment transported in suspension. The project will provide new insights into the drivers and mechanisms of fluvial geomorphology, thereby transforming fundamental analytical capabilities with regard to these key geomorphological processes. The project will incorporate a multifaceted educational plan that promotes research, teaching, and participation of students in geography and the geosciences through a combination of research, mentoring, and outreach activities involving graduate, undergraduate, and middle school students as well as the general public. Project results will enhance public awareness of water resources and education through a long-term interpretive exhibit at the Alabama Museum of Natural History.

Bedload sediment transport is a significant driver of the physical, biological, and chemical dynamics in river systems, and it affects water quality and availability in river systems, river shape and ecological functioning, and coastal dynamics. The investigator will develop a new bedload flux module within an existing global-scale hydrological modeling framework. The analyses will focus on the universal applicability of the physically based bedload module for large-scale simulations and on the spatial trends of the ratio between suspended and bedload fluxes along river systems as well as its relationship to river basin characteristics. To facilitate these analyses and to validate the model, a globally distributed observational database will be collected from existing U.S. Geological Survey databases, scholarly literature, online resources, and the investigator's collaborative network. Outcomes from this research will provide one of the first spatially and temporally explicit first-order estimates of global bedload flux and a numerical framework for studying the parameters, drivers, and mechanisms of bedload flux in large global rivers. The quantification of sediment transport in rivers will be catalytic for examining carbon and nutrient cycles, river, coastal and marine ecology, dam sustainability, and water and food security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview: 

Bedload sediment transport is a significant driver of the physical and biological functioning in river systems. While much research has been dedicated to quantifying and modeling small-scale transport mechanisms, the dynamics of bedload at large scales (basins, continents and global) has not been explored. This is largely due to the lack of observational data, a systemic issue in large-scale riverine research that is particularly acute for bedload. Responding to these knowledge gaps, this project leveraged the PIs global riverine research to study the dynamics of bedload sediment flux with a novel computer modeling framework. A bedload model was developed within an extensive hydrological modeling framework that already includes, among other parameters, a suspended sediment flux module (WBMsed; developed by the PI). The new bedload module was used in this project to simulate bedload flux based on an established bedload transport formula. With an overarching goal of elucidating global bedload dynamics, the proposed project included two main research goals: (1) analysis of the universal applicability of the physically-based bedload module to global scale simulations; (2) analysis of the spatial trends of the ratio between suspended and bedload fluxes along river systems and its relationship to river basin characteristics. To facilitate these analyses and validate the model, a globally distributed observational database was collected from literature, online resources, and personal contacts. The project included a multifaceted educational and outreach scheme to promote geo-computation research, teaching, and participation of students in the geosciences. The project combined research, mentoring and outreach activities involving graduate, undergraduate, school students, and the general public. One graduate student was supported while others were involved in the project's research and education activities. Three undergraduate students were partly supported by this project. The PI and students contributed to programs and events at the Alabama Museum of Natural History (AMNH) for middle and high school students and the general public. A permanent interactive exhibit (Augmented Reality Sandbox) was built for the AMNH to promote statewide water-related awareness and education.

Activities and Outcomes: 

Research ? A new river bedload flux module was developed within the global WBMsed modeling framework. This resulting model is the first of its kind global-scale bedload model. An observation dataset was compiled for model validation and analysis. This is the first dataset which focuses on large global rivers. A new, also first of its kind, global river slope geospatial dataset (termed GloRS) was developed and was used as input to the bedload model. A journal paper about GloRS was published in 2018 at the Journal of Hydrology and the dataset itself is openly and freely available on the PI?s server (accessible via https://sdml.ua.edu/datasets-2/). A new international collaboration between the PI and two German colleagues stemmed from this project, resulting in a paper at the Applied Geography journal in 2018.

Cohen, S., T. Wan,  M.T. Islam, J.P.M. Syvitski, (2018), Global River Slope: A New Geospatial Dataset and Global-scale Analysis. Journal of Hydrology, 568, 1057-1067.

Moosdorf, N., S. Cohen, C. von Hagke, (2018). A global erodibility index to represent sediment production potential of different rock types. Applied Geography, 101, 36-44. 

A manuscript focusing on the global bedload model is currently in advance stages of preparation. Once the paper is published, the model code and simulation results will be published in an open-source model repository (NSF-funded CSDMS) and the PI?s open server. Another journal paper, stemming from this project, is currently under review at the Global and Planetary Change journal. Results stemming from this project were presented in multiple conferences by the PI, students, and colleagues (totaling over 10 oral and poster presentations since 2017). 

Mentorship ? a graduate student (MSc) was funded by this project. He graduated and defended his thesis in the summer of 2018. A total of three undergraduate students were mentored as part of this project. Two of the students were female, one of whom is African-American. All the students gained valuable skills in environmental modeling, data analysis, scientific presentations (all presented in conferences). Two students were involved in journal paper development (co-authors on two of the papers).

Education and Outreach ? two Augmented Reality Sandbox were built with funding from this project. The first was placed as a permanent display at the Alabama Museum of Natural History (AMNH) in 2017 and has quickly become their most popular exhibit. It was even featured in the ABC-Birmingham evening news (https://abc3340.com/news/local/augmented-reality-sandbox-on-uas-campus-helps-educate-public-about-hydrological-processes). The 2ndSandbox was built as a mobile outreach exhibit and is stationed at the PI?s department (popular stop for students and visitors). Since 2017 the sandboxes have been used by the PI and his students in multiple K-12, public outreach, and professional events, including:

  • The AMNH Summer Camp 
  • AMNH Science Sunday-Alabama Waterways event 
  • AMNH Innovation Fair
  • Rock Quarry Elementary ?Learning through the Decades? event
  • Global Flood Partnership Annual Meeting
  • SEC Water Conference
